@@ -0,0 +1,71 @@
+﻿function Uninstall-ChocolateyPackage {
+<#
+.SYNOPSIS
+Uninstalls a package
+
+.DESCRIPTION
+This will uninstall a package on your machine.
+
+.PARAMETER PackageName
+The name of the package 
+
+.PARAMETER FileType
+This is the extension of the file. This should be either exe or msi.
+
+.PARAMETER SilentArgs
+Please include the notSilent tag in your chocolatey nuget package if you are not setting up a silent package.
+
+.PARAMETER File
+The full path to the native uninstaller to run
+
+.EXAMPLE
+Uninstall-ChocolateyPackage '__NAME__' 'EXE_OR_MSI' 'SILENT_ARGS' 'FilePath'
+
+.OUTPUTS
+None
+
+.NOTES
+This helper reduces the number of lines one would have to write to run an uninstaller to 1 line.
+There is no error handling built into this method.
+
+.LINK
+Uninstall-ChocolateyPackage
+#>
+param(
+  [string] $packageName, 
+  [string] $fileType = 'exe',
+  [string] $silentArgs = '',
+  [string] $file,
+  $validExitCodes = @(0)
+)
+  $installMessage = "Uninstalling $packageName..."
+  write-host $installMessage
+
+  $additionalInstallArgs = $env:chocolateyInstallArguments;
+  if ($additionalInstallArgs -eq $null) { $additionalInstallArgs = ''; }
+  $overrideArguments = $env:chocolateyInstallOverride;
+    
+  if ($fileType -like 'msi') {
+    $msiArgs = "/x `"$file`""

I just saw this comment.   short of knowing the md5/sha-1 of the file before download, there is no way to know if the remote file is the same or not (a la http://download.tuxfamily.org/notepadplus/6.3.2/npp.6.3.2.digest.sha1).  That is a can of worms bigger than this commit.  

That said, I think based on @ferventcoder note-

$chocTempDir/foo-1.0.4/Install-foo-1.0.4.msi

will ensure no contamination from a same filename installer.

body:
maybe I just don't remember batch scripting, but it appears at first glance you are assuminganything GTR 2 parameters after cinst (aka install)  are both package names.  in that use case it works, and nicely I might add.

in the case of cinst putty -Version 0.62.0.1,  this logic appears flawed based on my screen paste, since it is trying to batch install a package named "-version"
I prefer to put this in the .cmd file next to all of the other options.
I wonder if this should result in an error.

Try the current situation, It's certainly wrong. getting a 

>    Finished installing '' and dependencies

Doesn't seem right, and is different behavior than any package installer I know (gem, pip, easy_install, apt-get, aptiture etc').
What would you expect as a user to get when running without a parameter?
Great Idea, I'm not much of Powershell programmer, so I missed it. You'll need to change the tests accordingly
Or do you mean `Write-Debug` as the error? probably right about that, should we use Write-Host only?
No, sorry. I meant this should return an exit code of 1
I think returning an exit code of 1 would help integrate chocolatey installs in CI workflows. But the user should get a simple message, what hadn't happened and not a big error stack

body:
Incidentally, I have solved the environment problem in a PowerShell script I'm using to configure a freshly started virtual machine: https://gist.github.com/jberezanski/01319436ca0c78a60120 (which contains workarounds for other issues as well). The key is to always stay in PowerShell (invoke Chocolatey using chocolatey.ps1 instead of cmd wrappers), that way the environment can be controlled and corrected when needed. I'm currently in the process of submitting most of the patches implemented in that script as pull requests.

If your TeamCity build script is (or can be) written in PowerShell, you can use a similar technique to ensure Chocolatey PATH additions are visible immediately after installation. In that case the Exec command in build.ps1 can be simplified to `nuget pack "%(NuspecFiles.FullPath)" -NoPackageAnalysis`.

body:
Yes, a deadlock will occur if the child process (nuget in this case) alternates between writing to standard error and standard output and writes enough data to exceed the size of the buffer of one of the pipes created under the covers.
A reliable solution would be to register for the OutputDataReceived and ErrorDataReceived events (using Register-ObjectEvent) and use async reads (BeginOutputReadLine, BeginErrorReadLine).

body:
OK, I've tested a bunch of approaches. I've found a few working ones, apart from Register-ObjectEvent.
My test code and test results (in comments, lines 143-186): https://gist.github.com/jberezanski/f329ec1ccdf9c7dfb5ae

The Register-ObjectEvent approach is not only one of the slowest, but also, surprisingly, unreliable! Due to the async nature of PowerShell event dispatch, there is no guarantee that all output events will be delivered by the time the child process ends. Without the Start-Sleep after WaitForExit(), I was getting random test failures (empty error output).

The fastest reliable approach involves using a Task obtained from $process.StandardError.ReadToEndAsync(), but this method is only available on .NET 4.0, so requires PowerShell 3 or better. This approach also results in cleanest code.

The second-best approach uses Delegate.BeginInvoke() to call ReadToEnd() asynchronously. I could not find a suitable delegate signature in pure .NET 2.0 and had to use Func<T>, available in .NET 3.5 upwards. This approach works in PowerShell 2.0 if .NET 3.5 is installed.

The fastest approach supporting pure .NET 2.0 is the one where a dynamic method is generated from MSIL.

(Note that I was comparing the approaches based on first invocation time, where the difference is most noticeable. Second and later invocations are equally fast in all approaches except Register-ObjectEvent.)
